data.value: To view information about a specific location, click on the map...

data.name: noPlaceInfo

data.name: helpContent_prague
data.value:
What is MemoMap?

Interactive map of Prague from the period of the Protectorate Bohemia and Moravia. The map shows the addresses where Prague Jews lived during Nazi occupation, places related to their persecution as well as places where Jews were not allowed. Thanks to the timeline, you can see how people gradually disappeared from their homes as they were deported to ghettos and concentration camps. The app is adapted for mobile devices and you can use it while walking in the city.

What does MemoMap contain?

The app displays information about more than 40,000 victims of the Holocaust, about 1,700 cases of violations of anti-Jewish regulations and ordinances, about 120 places of interest related to their daily lives and persecution, about 110 places that were inaccessible to Jewish residents of Prague during the war and a growing number of places of memory.

The data on the victims of the Holocaust come from a database maintained by the Terezín Initiative Institute. The application makes available not only photographs of the victims, but also scans of the police records relating to violations of anti-Jewish regulations and orders (these scans come from the Prague Police Directorate's collection at the National Archives).

How to use the application?

Individual data types are divided into so-called layers, between which you can switch. The layer control is located under the icon  

You can Zoom in or out on the map using the  

Your location on the map can be found using the button  

Did you find an error?

If you encounter a technical problem or data error, please let us know using this forms.

Credit

The MemoMap application was originally developed as part of the project Integration and Segregation in the City Space: the History of the Holocaust in Prague through a mobile web application (identifier TL01000366). The project was supported by the Technology Agency of the Czech Republic as part of the public competition ÉTA 1. MemoMap was created by the Masaryk Institute and Archives of the Czech Academy of Sciences in cooperation with the Terezín Initiative Institute and the Multicultural Centre Prague.

The application is maintained and further developed by the Czech node of the European Holocaust Research Infrastructure. It is part of the LINDAT/CLARIAH-CZ infrastructure, which is supported by the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic under the programm of large research infrastructures.

It has been supported by the Czech Foundation for Holocast Victims and through the Strategy AV21 program "City as a laboratory of change" financed by the Czech Academy of Sciences.

The map shows the addresses where Prague Jews lived during Nazi occupation, places related to their persecution as well as places where Jews were not allowed. data.name: survivorsNotDisplayed
data.value: Survivors and people of unknown fate aren't displayed below.

data.name: layer_interest_title_prague
data.value: Points of Interest in the City of Prague

data.name: layer_interest_abstract_prague
data.value: Points of interest include places of persecution, Jewish buildings, warehouses full of confiscated property, or places that Jews were forbidden to enter.

data.name: layer_incident_title_prague
data.value: Incidents Within the City of Prague

data.name: layer_incident_abstract_prague
data.value: Incidents that took place within the city limits of Prague during which Jewish residents were arrested or investigated for violating anti-Jewish ordinances. This data was extracted from the digitized documents of the Prague Police as part of the MemoMap Prague project. It includes information about non-compliance with restrictions of free movement, identification papers lacking the letter \"J\" (Jude), etc.

data.name: layer_address_title_prague
data.value: Jewish Homes in Prague During the Occupation

data.name: layer_address_abstract_prague
data.value: Addresses where Jewish residents of Prague lived during the Shoah, according to the victims' database. The data mostly come from the registration of Jews in the Protectorate, which was initiated in autumn 1941 by order of the Central Office for Jewish Emigration. Therefore, they may not correspond to the residence of Jewish families before the persecution began. The layer includes data on the number of occupants of each house, statistics on their fate and the number present on various historical dates. In some cases, where individual houses were difficult to identify, multiple addresses are grouped under the same coordinates (for example, on the same street). We are continuously working on refining the map location. Street names from the time of occupation (ca. 1941-1942) are used.

data.name: layer_victim_abstract_prague
data.value: Database of Jewish residents of Prague who were persecuted by the Nazis and died as a result. The records are linked to their Prague addresses. Details are accessible via links to holocaust.cz.

data.name: layer_inaccessible_title_prague
data.value: Forbidden Places Within the City of Prague

data.name: layer_inaccessible_abstract_prague
data.value: Places that were forbidden to Jews during the war. Their depiction is based on a historical map from 1938. The current spaces may vary in size and shape.

data.name: layer_statistics_abstract_prague
data.value: Outlines of historical Prague and Prague districts from 1930 supplemented with data on the number of records accessible in the application. The map is based on the output of the NAKI project "Making Historical Spatial and Statistical Data Available in a GIS Environment" (project number DF12P01OVV033) and further modified.

data.name: layer_MGS-prague_historical_map_1938-v2_abstract_prague
data.value: Orientation plan of the capital city of Prague and its surroundings (1938). The digital version was prepared by the Municipal Library in Prague, georeferencing was carried out by the Masaryk Institute and the Archive of the Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic. Also available from WWW: http://web2.mlp.cz/mapa1938/klad.php.

data.name: zoomMapForMoreInfo
data.value: Zoom in on the map for more information.

data.name: welcomeText_prague_short
data.value: The addresses of over 40,000 Holocaust victims, 1,700 police incidents, and sites restricted for Jews. A 1938 historical map of Prague.

data.name: welcomeText_prague_long
data.value:
Before the Second World War, nearly forty thousand Jews lived in Prague; approximately seven and a half thousand survived. In MemoMap Prague, users can explore the fates of Jewish victims through six data layers.

The Jewish residents  layer contains more than eight thousand addresses where Jewish residents lived during the occupation. Information on residences usually comes from the registration of Jews in the Protectorate, initiated in autumn 1941. In many cases, it therefore reflects the situation after forced relocation to another district or consolidation into shared flats. Clicking on a specific address displays not only the total number of Jewish residents and statistics on their wartime fates, but also the names and photographs of victims, including links to detailed information on the holocaust.cz portal administered by the Terezín Initiative Institute.

The Points of Interest layer shows places connected with the everyday lives of Prague’s Jewish inhabitants and later with their persecution. These include, for example, synagogues that gradually lost their religious function and were transformed into warehouses for confiscated Jewish property.

The Incidents layer enables users to explore interactions between the persecuted population and other residents, the Protectorate police, and occupying authorities within the urban space, as well as their behaviour and resistance in the face of social exclusion. Approximately 1,700 cases drawn from Prague police records primarily document situations in which Jews came into conflict due to alleged violations of anti-Jewish regulations and decrees.

The Places of Memory layer is dedicated to monuments and memorials commemorating Holocaust victims in today’s public space, including the Stolpersteine (stumbling stones). The data on these plaques may be different from the residences Jews were forced to live in before they were relocated.

Through a timeline, users can follow the gradual “disappearance” of Jewish residents as a result of deportations to ghettos and concentration camps. The application thus illustrates the destruction of Prague’s linguistically, ethnically, and religiously diverse society.

Exclusion from public space can be traced through the Forbidden Places layer. The list of these locations is based on contemporary decrees, and their outlines follow a historical map from 1938.

Data preparation and application development were made possible – in addition to support from the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic – thanks to support from the Endowment Fund for Holocaust Victims and the Strategy 21 programme of the Czech Academy of Sciences, The City as a Laboratory of Change.

Go to MemoMap Prague.

data.name: welcomeText_prague_last_residence
data.value: An interactive map of Prague during the Protectorate shows the addresses of more than 40,000 Holocaust victims, 1,700 cases of violations of anti-Jewish ordinances, important places associated with Jewish history and persecution, and places where Jews were not allowed during the war.

data.name: helpContent_pacov
data.value:
What does MemoMap Pacov contain?

An interactive map of the Jewish community in Pacov shows the residences of more than 100 Jewish inhabitants of the town, as well as places connected with the Jewish history of Pacov and the everyday coexistence of the Jewish and majority populations. It also offers so-called story maps, which allow users to follow specific personal stories and their trajectories in detail. The data is supplemented by digitized documents and photographs that further illustrate the stories of people and places.

The map is based on multiple sources, such as archival records and personal documents, so the information in individual records may vary slightly.

The data is based on available Holocaust victim databases, archival sources, and scholarly publications. The preparation of data and texts involved pupils from local primary schools and the Municipal Office of Říčany.

How to use the application?

Individual data types are divided into so-called layers, between which you can switch. The layer control is located under the icon  

You can Zoom in or out on the map using the  

Your location on the map can be found using the button  

Credits

The MemoMap Pacov application was created in cooperation with the non-profit organization Tikkun Pacov. Special thanks go to Mr. Pavel Tychtl, who made his extensive collection of documents and photographs available for the application and provided a wealth of valuable information.

The development of the map application was supported by the Foundation for Holocaust Victims.

The application is continuously developed and maintained within the Czech node of the European Holocaust Research Infrastructure. EHRI-CZ is part of the LINDAT/CLARIAH-CZ infrastructure, which is fully supported by the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic as part of the "large infrastructures" program.

data.name: welcomeText_pacov_short
data.value: The homes of Pacov’s Jewish residents. Stories of the victims. A 1942 historical map of Pacov.

data.name: welcomeText_pacov_long
data.value:
The beginnings of Jewish presence in Pacov date back to the second half of the 16th century. Approximately a hundred years later, a religious community was established, which for a long time developed in a predominantly Catholic environment without major conflicts. At the beginning of the 19th century, Pacov even became the seat of a regional rabbi. From the 18th century onwards, Jewish houses were concentrated mainly in today’s Autengruberova and Hronova Streets, while the school and rabbinical residence were located in Malovcova Street.

The Jewish population reached its peak in the second half of the 19th century, when more than 200 Jews lived in Pacov, but subsequently declined due to migration. Although they formed only a small part of the population, they played a significant role in the city’s economic and public life. Before the Second World War, 96 persons of Jewish origin were registered in Pacov. Deportations began in November 1942 via the assembly point in Tábor, from where Pacov’s Jews were deported mainly to the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp, where almost all of them were murdered.

Unlike MemoMap Prague, MemoMap Pacov works with a smaller amount of data, allowing selected personal stories to be explored in greater detail. The application displays the residences of Jewish inhabitants, places connected with local Jewish history, and sites related to everyday coexistence between the Jewish and majority populations. A major innovation is the inclusion of so-called Story Maps, which trace individual human stories and their spatial trajectories in detail. The presented data is complemented by digitised documents and photographs that further illuminate the stories of people and places.

MemoMap Pacov was developed in cooperation with the non-profit organisation Tikkun Pacov. Special thanks go to Mr Pavel Tychtl, who made his extensive collection of documents and photographs available for the application and provided valuable information on local Jewish history.

Data preparation and application development were made possible – in addition to support from the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic – thanks to support from the Endowment Fund for Holocaust Victims.

Go to MemoMap Pacov.

data.name: welcomeText_ricany_short
data.value: The sites of Jewish life in Říčany. Commemorative event footage. A 1935 historical map of Říčany.

data.name: welcomeText_ricany_long
data.value:
Jewish presence in Říčany is documented from at least the 19th century and was most prominent during the interwar period. At that time, several dozen Jewish residents lived in the town and in the neighbouring villages of Radošovice and Strašín, mostly from merchant and artisan families. They were concentrated mainly around Masaryk Square and its surroundings and formed a natural part of the town’s everyday life, contributing to civic, cultural, and sporting activities. Religious life took place in a local prayer house, while administratively the Jews of Říčany belonged to the religious community in Uhříněves.

A turning point came with the Nazi occupation. In 1942, deportations began, and most of Říčany’s Jews were first concentrated in the Theresienstadt ghetto, from where they were deported to extermination camps, primarily Auschwitz, Treblinka, and Sobibor. At least 73 Jewish residents from Říčany and its surroundings were murdered; only a small number survived through emigration, hiding, or liberation from the camps. After the war, the Jewish community was not re-established, and the memory of former Jewish residents was suppressed for decades.

The gradual return of Jewish history to public space began only after 1989. A memorial plaque to the victims of the Holocaust, Stolpersteine (stumbling stones), and an information point on Masaryk Square now commemorate individual human stories. An important element of Říčany’s memory is also the story of the local Torah scroll, which after the war eventually reached London.

MemoMap Říčany works with a historical map of the town from 1935. It displays the residences of local Jewish families and places connected with their everyday lives. A new feature is the Remembrance Events data layer, which provides information on memorial and commemorative activities in the town and links historical data with contemporary forms of remembrance. The application thus enables users to explore history while also perceiving its presence in today’s public space.

MemoMap Říčany was created with the involvement of local residents of Říčany, pupils from Bezručova Primary School and U Říčanského lesa Primary School, and staff from the Říčany Museum and the Municipal Office of Říčany. Special thanks go to Ms Věra Likešová and Markéta Žilková from the Municipal Office of Říčany.

Data preparation and application development were made possible – in addition to support from the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic – thanks to support from the Endowment Fund for Holocaust Victims.

Go to MemoMap Říčany.

data.name: layer_address_abstract_ricany
data.value: Addresses where Jewish residents of Říčany lived during the occupation and in the period immediately preceding it, based on surviving sources. The information is compiled using publicly available Holocaust victim databases and archival materials.

data.name: layer_memory_abstract_ricany
data.value: Sites and objects commemorating the persecution and victims of the Holocaust. This layer includes information about the Stolpersteine (Stumble Stones) in Říčany and other memorials and commemorative sites across the town.

data.name: layer_memorial_abstract_ricany
data.value: Events in Říčany commemorating the victims of the Holocaust. Memorial events connected with the laying of Stolpersteine (Stumble Stones) and other remembrance gatherings.

data.name: layer_MGS-pacov_historical_map_1942-cze-v1_abstract_pacov
data.value: The historical map of Pacov dates back to May 1942. The red coloured areas with house numbers mark Jewish buildings and properties. The map comes from the State District Archive in Pelhřimov, georeferencing was carried out by the Masaryk Institute and the Archive of the Czech Academy of Sciences.

data.name: helpContent_ricany
data.value:
About MemoMap Říčany

An interactive map of the Jewish community in Říčany shows the residences and stories of nearly one hundred Jewish residents of the town, as well as places connected with their lives, current memorial and commemorative sites, and the story of the Říčany Torah.

The former Jewish community in Říčany only began to be openly addressed again after the Velvet Revolution. In 2012, a memorial plaque to the victims of the Holocaust was unveiled at the Old Town Hall in Říčany. In 2017, the first Stolpersteine, or "stumbling stones," were laid on Masaryk Square. Three years later, an information stand about the stones of the disappeared was set up in the old tobacco shop on the square. The stones, which we are meant to stumble over every day so that we do not forget the past, are still increasing in number. In 2025, there will be 31 of them, and that is far from the final number.

In recent years, we have also been commemorating the victims of Říčany together with representatives of the Finchley Reform Synagogue in London. That is where the Říčany Torah ended up after leaving our town and then Prague and Czechoslovakia in 1962.

In 2025, we expanded our commemoration of local Jewish history by creating an interactive MemoMap. It uses a historical map of Říčany from 1935 and offers several thematic layers that capture the fates of local Holocaust victims, places associated with their lives, and other traces of Jewish history in the town. MemoMap allows visitors to explore history directly in the field and brings it closer to current visitors and residents.

What does MemoMap contain?

The application presents information about Jewish families from Říčany, their homes, and places connected to their everyday lives. It also features local sites of memory and the Torah scrolls that were once used in Říčany and are now located in the United Kingdom. The application further includes data on commemorative events, such as Stolperstein placements.

The data is based on available Holocaust victim databases, archival sources, and scholarly publications. The preparation of data and texts involved pupils from local primary schools and the Municipal Office of Říčany.

How to use the application?

Individual data types are divided into so-called layers, between which you can switch. The layer control is located under the icon  

You can Zoom in or out on the map using the  

Your location on the map can be found using the button  

Credits

MemoMap Říčany was created through the collaboration of the Masaryk Institute and Archives of the Czech Academy of Sciences and the Municipal Office of Říčany. Special thanks go to Ms Věra Likešová and Ms Markéta Žilková from the Říčany Municipal Office.

The development of the map application was supported by the Foundation for Holocaust Victims.

The application is continuously developed and maintained within the Czech node of the European Holocaust Research Infrastructure. EHRI-CZ is part of the LINDAT/CLARIAH-CZ infrastructure, which is fully supported by the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic as part of the "large infrastructures" program.

data.name: storyMapExistsForPlace
data.value: There is a story map for a given place.

data.name: welcomeText_short
data.value: MemoMap is a web-based application built on a Historical Geographic Information System (HGIS) that connects scholarly research with specific urban spaces. It enables users to explore the history of the Holocaust and Nazi persecution through the places of everyday life. The application can be used not only on a home or school computer, but also directly while walking through the city via mobile devices. Different types of data are organised into so-called layers, which users can switch between and combine according to their interests. This makes it possible to explore history directly in physical space and to perceive changes in the urban environment over time.

data.name: layer_HGC-BordersProtectorateBM-v2_title_pacov
data.value: Border of the Protectorate Bohemia and Moravia

data.name: layer_HGC-BordersProtectorateBM-v2_abstract_pacov
data.value: The original borders of the Protectorate Bohemia and Moravia were taken from a dataset created as a part of a project which documents monthly European border changes from 1938-1945. The data are much better presented with accurate military front lines, data which has not been fully digitized but would constitute a valuable addition to the research.

data.name: layer_HGC-BordersProtectorateBM-v2_title_ricany
data.value: Border of the Protectorate Bohemia and Moravia

data.name: layer_HGC-BordersProtectorateBM-v2_abstract_ricany
data.value: The original borders of the Protectorate Bohemia and Moravia were taken from a dataset created as a part of a project which documents monthly European border changes from 1938-1945. The data are much better presented with accurate military front lines, data which has not been fully digitized but would constitute a valuable addition to the research.

data.name: help_storymap_ricany
data.value: The Story of the Ríčany Torah

data.name: welcomeText_long
data.value:
MemoMap is a web-based application built on a Historical Geographic Information System (HGIS) that connects scholarly research with specific urban spaces. It enables users to explore the history of the Holocaust and Nazi persecution through the places of everyday life.

The application can be used not only on a home or school computer, but also directly while walking through the city via mobile devices. Different types of data are organised into so-called layers, which users can switch between and combine according to their interests. This makes it possible to explore history directly in physical space and to perceive changes in the urban environment over time.

MemoMap offers insight into the microhistory of the exclusion of the Jewish population from society – restrictions on movement, access to public space, and changes in relationships between residents of occupied towns and cities. The application provides a new perspective on familiar shared urban spaces. For schools, it enables new questions about the Holocaust and racial segregation to be asked using modern technology. For tourists and guides, it offers a new experience when discovering cities with a multi-ethnic past.

The MemoMap application was created by the Masaryk Institute and Archives of the Czech Academy of Sciences as a service of the Czech node of the European Holocaust Research Infrastructure (EHRI-CZ). EHRI-CZ is part of the LINDAT/CLARIAH-CZ infrastructure, which is fully supported by the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic under the programme of “large research infrastructures”.

In the future, we plan to continue developing the MemoMap project and to expand it with additional locations and data. If you have supplementary information, archival materials, or other sources that could be used in MemoMap, please do not hesitate to contact us via the form below.

MemoMaps are currently available for the following cities: Prague, Pacov, and Říčany.

data.name: welcomeText_prague
data.value: An interactive map of Prague during the Protectorate shows the addresses of more than 40,000 Holocaust victims, 1,700 cases of violations of anti-Jewish ordinances, important places associated with Jewish history and persecution, and places where Jews were not allowed during the war. The timeline shows how people gradually disappeared from their homes. The app is adapted for mobile devices, so you can take it directly to the city.

data.name: welcomeText_pacov
data.value: An interactive map of the Jewish community in Pacov shows the residences of more than 100 Jewish residents of the town, as well as places connected with the Jewish history of Pacov, and the everyday coexistence of the Jewish and majority populations. It also offers so-called story maps, which allow users to follow specific personal stories and their trajectories in detail. The data is supplemented with digitized documents and photographs. MemoMap Pacov was created in collaboration with the non-profit organization Tikkun Pacov, with special thanks to Mr. Pavel Tychtl. The application is adapted for mobile devices, so you can take it with you directly to the town.

data.name: welcomeText_ricany
data.value: An interactive map of the Jewish community in Říčany shows the residences and stories of nearly one hundred Jewish residents of the town, as well as places connected with their lives, current memorial and commemorative sites, and the story of the Říčany Torah. The map captures the process of gradually commemorating the Jewish history of Říčany after 1989, including the unveiling of a memorial plaque to Holocaust victims at the Old Town Hall in 2012, the installation of the first Stolpersteine in 2017, and the creation of an information booth. The interactive MemoMap has been in development since 2025 in collaboration with students from Bezručova Elementary School No. 2 and Říčanský les Elementary School No. 3, the City of Říčany, and the Říčany Museum. The application is adapted for mobile devices, so you can take it with you directly to the town.
